facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 404 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 404 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 29, 1963 of the Kerala High Court in O.P. No. 2165 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 29, 1963 of the Kerala High Court in O.P. No. 2165 of 1962. R. L. lyengar and M. R. Krishna Pillai, for the appellants.

facts.text: The respondent was a dealer in Cocoanut oil business having inter-State sales.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent  hereinafter called the assessee  was a dealer in Cocoanut oil business having inter-State sales.

facts.text: For the year 1959-60 the assessee was assessed to sales-tax under s. 8 of the Central Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: For the year 1959-60 the assessee was assessed to sales-tax under s. 8 of the Central Sales Tax Act  Act 74 of 1.956 , hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Total turnover determined by the Sales Tax Officer was Rs. 2,30,990 and odd.

anchor.surface_text: Out of a total turnover of Rs. 2,30,990 and odd determined by the Sales Tax Officer, only a sum of Rs. 1,89,734 and odd was supported by proper declaration Form C.

facts.text: Only a sum of Rs. 1,89,734 and odd was supported by proper declaration Form C.

anchor.surface_text: Out of a total turnover of Rs. 2,30,990 and odd determined by the Sales Tax Officer, only a sum of Rs. 1,89,734 and odd was supported by proper declaration Form C.

facts.text: Tax imposed at 1% on turnover of Rs. 1,93,346 and at 7% on balance Rs. 37,645.

anchor.surface_text: Tax was therefore imposed by the Sales Tax Officer at the rate of 1 on the turnover of Rs. 1,93,346 and at 7 on the balance, namely Rs. 37,645.

facts.text: Assessee did not file declaration forms on or before February 16, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee did number file the declaration forms on or before the prescribed date, i.e., February 16, 1961 but he actually filed the declaration forms on March 8, 1961

facts.text: Assessee filed declaration forms on March 8, 1961 before the order of assessment.

anchor.surface_text: but he actually filed the declaration forms on March 8, 1961 before the order of assessment was made, the delay being explained as due to late receipt of the declaration forms

facts.text: Delay explained as due to late receipt of declaration forms from purchaser in Madras.

anchor.surface_text: the delay being explained as due to late receipt of the declaration forms from the purchaser in Madras.

facts.text: Assessee preferred appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner which was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee preferred an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner but the appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: Revision petition before Deputy Commissioner of Sales-tax dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee took the matter in revision before the Deputy Commissioner of Sales-tax but the revision petition was dismissed.

facts.text: Assessee moved Kerala High Court for writ under Art. 226 to quash STO order dated June 13, 1961 and AAC order dated December 13, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the assessee moved the Kerala High Court for grant of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution for quashing the orders of the Sales Tax Officer dated June 13, 1961 and the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner dated December 13, 1961.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer order dated June 13, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: quashing the orders of the Sales Tax Officer dated June 13, 1961

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner order dated December 13, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner dated December 13, 1961.

facts.text: Kerala High Court by order dated November 29, 1963 allowed writ petition, quashed assessment orders and directed fresh assessment considering declarations filed on March 8, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated November 29, 1963, the High Court allowed the writ petition of the assessee and quashed the orders of assessment of sales-tax and directed the Sales Tax Officer to make a fresh order of assessment after taking into companysideration the declaration forms furnished by the as on March 8, 1961.

facts.text: Third proviso to Rule 6(1) required submission of declaration forms not later than 16-2-1961.

anchor.surface_text: Provided also that all declaration forms pending submission by dealers on 2-5-1960 shall be submitted number later than 16-2-1961.

facts.text: First proviso to Rule 6 inserted by notification dated January 3, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The first proviso to Rule 6 was inserted by numberification dated January 3, 1958, the second by numberification dated April 26, 1960

facts.text: Assessee furnished declarations on March 8, 1961 before assessment order; admitted position.

anchor.surface_text: it is the admitted position that the assessee did furnish the declarations on March 8, 1961 before the order of assessment was made by the Sales Tax Officer.

facts.text: Appellants contended assessee not entitled to lower rate due to breach of Rule 6(1) third proviso.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended on behalf of the appellants that the assessee had number filed the declarations in form C before February 16, 1961 according to the third proviso to Rule 6 1  and in view of the breach of this Rule

facts.text: Supreme Court held assessee furnished declarations within reasonable time complying with s.8(4)(a).

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the assessee has furnished the declarations in Form C in the present case within a ,reasonable time and there has been a companypliance with the requirements of s. 8  4   a  of the Act.

facts.text: High Court was right in quashing STO assessment order.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the High Court was right in quashing the order of assessment made by the Sales Tax Officer and directing him to make a fresh order of assessment
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 29, 1963 of the Kerala High Court in O.P. No. 2165 of 1962. R. L. lyengar and M. R. Krishna Pillai, for the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Section 13 states The Central Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, make rules providing for- a the manner in which applications for registration may be made under this Act, the particulars to be contained therein, the procedure for the grant of such registration, the circumstances in which registration may be refused and the form in. which the certificate of registration may be given b the period of turnover, the manner in which the turnover in relation to the sale of any goods under this Act shall be determined, and the deductions which may be made in the process of such determination c the cases and circumstances in which, and the conditions subject to which, any registration granted under this Act may be cancelled d the form in which and the particulars to be contained in any declaration or certificate to be given under this Act The, State Government may make rules, not inconsistent with the provisions of this Act and the rules made under sub-section  1 , to carry out the purposes of this Act.

concepts.interpretation: Empowers rule-making for forms, declarations, manner etc., but distinguishes 'manner' from 'time within which'

anchor.surface_text: Rule 6 of the Central Sales Tax  Kerala  Rules, 1967 read as follows 6.  1  Every dealer registered under section 7 of the Act and every dealer liable to pay under the Act shall submit a return of all his transaction including those in the course of export of the goods out of the territory of India in Form 11 together with connected decla- 5 2 2 ration forms so as to reach the assessing authority on or before the 20th of ea ch month showing the turnover for the preceding month and the amount or amounts collected by way of tax together with proof for the payment of tax due thereon under the Act.

concepts.interpretation: First proviso allows submission before assessment; second limits delay to 3 months from sale; third held ultra vires

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: of the appellants that the assessee had number filed the declarations in form C before February 16, 1961 according to the third proviso to Rule 6 1  a

concepts.unlisted_description: Governs submission of returns and declaration forms

issues.text: Whether the third proviso to Rule 6(1) was ultra vires of s. 8(4) read with s. 13(4)(e) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: put forward on behalf of the assessee and it was argued that the third proviso to Rule 6  1  was ultra vires of s. 8  4  read with s. 1 3  4   e  of the Act. The de- cision of the question at issue therefore depends on the construction of the

issues.text: Whether the phrase 'in the prescribed manner' in s. 8(4) read with s. 13 of the Act authorises prescription of a time-limit for furnishing declarations

anchor.surface_text: construction of the phrase in the prescribed manner in s. 8  4  read with s. 13 of the Act. In our opinion, the phrase in the prescribed manner occurring in s. 8 4  of the Act only confers power on the rule-making authority to prescribe a rule stating what particulars are to be mentioned in the prescribed form, the nature and value of the goods

issues.text: Whether the assessee furnished the declarations in Form C within a reasonable time before assessment

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of any such time-limit it was the duty of the assessee to furnish the declarations in form C within a reasonable time, and in the present case it is the admitted position that the assessee did furnish the declarations on March 8, 1961 before the order of assessment was made by the Sales Tax Officer. We are accordingly of the opinion that the assessee has furnished the declarations in Form C in the present case within a ,reasonable time and there has been a compliance with the requirements of s. 8  4   a  of the Act.

arguments.claim: The assessee was not entitled to the lower rate of assessment under s. 8(1) of the Act due to breach of the third proviso to Rule 6(1) by not filing declarations before February 16, 1961

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the appellants that the assessee had not filed the declarations in form C before February 16, 1961 according to the third proviso to Rule 6(1) and in view of the breach of this Rule the assessee was not entitled to take advantage of the lower rate of assessment under s. 8(1) of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: arrant shall be null and void ,against the assignees. The words in manner and form refer only to the mode in which the thing is to, be done, and do nu

arguments.court_reasoning: Third proviso to Rule 6(1) is ultra vires s.8(4) read with s.13(3) and (4) as 'prescribed manner' does not include time-limits

arguments.claim: The third proviso to Rule 6(1) was ultra vires of s. 8(4) read with s. 13(4)(e) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The opposite view-point was put forward on behalf of the assessee and it was argued that the third proviso to Rule 6(1) was ultra vires of s. 8(4) read with s. 13(4)(e) of the Act. The decision of the question at issue therefore depends on the construction of the

court_response_anchor.surface_text: arrant shall be null and void ,against the assignees. The words in manner and form refer only to the mode in which the thing is to, be done, and do nu

arguments.court_reasoning: Phrase 'in the prescribed manner' in s.8(4) does not empower prescribing time-limits for furnishing declarations

arguments.claim: The phrase 'in the prescribed manner' in s.8(4) only covers particulars in form, nature/value of goods, parties, authority, but does not include time element or authorise time-limits

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the phrase in the prescribed manner occurring in s. 8(4) of the Act only confers power on the rule-making authority to prescribe a rule stating what particulars are to be mentioned in the prescribed form, the nature and value of the goods sold, the parties to whom they are sold, and to which authority the form is to be furnished.

arguments.claim: s.13(4)(g) supports interpretation as it separately specifies 'time within which' alongside 'manner', showing legislature knows how to prescribe time when intended

anchor.surface_text: The view that we have taken is supported by the language of s. 13(4)(g) of the Act which states that the State Government may make rules for the time within which, the manner in which and the authorities to whom any change in the ownership of any business or in the name, place or nature of any business carried on by any dealer shall be furnished.

arguments.claim: Stroud's Judicial Dictionary defines 'manner and form' as referring only to mode of doing, not the thing or time for doing it

anchor.surface_text: In Strouds Judicial Dictionary it is said that the words manner and form refer only to the mode in which the thing is to be done, and do not introduce anything from the Act referred to as to the thing which is to be done or the time for doing it.

arguments.claim: In Acraman v. Herniman, 'manner and form' interpreted as mode only, not time, rendering warrant void for non-compliance including affidavit time

anchor.surface_text: In Acraman v. Herniman the plaintiffs had become the assignees in bankruptcy proceedings against Garret who had executed on March 4, 1850 a warrant of attorney to the defendant Herniman on the strength of which the latter had obtained judgment against him and sold his goods.

arguments.claim: Note to Form C supports view as it refers to rules under s.13(4)(e) by State Govt.

anchor.surface_text: The view that we have expressed as to the interpretation of s. 8(4) of the Act is also supported by the Note to the form of declaration-Form C-prescribed by Rule 12 of the Central Sales Tax (Registration & Turnover) Rules, 1957.

arguments.claim: Third proviso to Rule 6(1) is ultra vires s.8(4) read with s.13(3) and (4); assessee not bound by Feb 16, 1961 deadline

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons expressed, we hold that the third proviso to Rule 6(1) is ultra vires of s. 8(4) read with s. 13(3) and (4) of the Act. It follows therefore that the assessee was not bound to furnish declarations in Form C before February 16, 1961 in the present case.

arguments.claim: Absent statutory time-limit, assessee must furnish declarations within reasonable time; here filed March 8, 1961 before assessment, delay due to late receipt explained

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of any such time-limit it was the duty of the assessee to furnish the declarations in form C within a reasonable time, and in the present case it is the admitted position that the assessee did furnish the declarations on March 8, 1961 before the order of assessment was made by the Sales Tax Officer.

arguments.claim: Assessee complied with s.8(4)(a) by furnishing declarations within reasonable time

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the assessee has furnished the declarations in Form C in the present case within a reasonable time and there has been a compliance with the requirements of s. 8(4)(a) of the Act.

arguments.claim: High Court correctly quashed assessment order and directed fresh assessment considering March 8 declarations

holdings.text: the third proviso to Rule 6(1) is ultra vires of s. 8(4) read with s. 13(3) and (4) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons expressed, we hold that the third proviso to Rule 6  1   is ultra vires of s. 8  4  read with s. 1 3  3   and  4  of the Act. It follows therefore that the assessee was

holdings.reasoning_summary: Phrase 'in the prescribed manner' in s.8(4) interpreted textually as mode excluding time-limits; supported by s.13(4)(g) distinguishing time/manner, Stroud's definition, Acraman v. Herniman precedent, Form C note

holdings.text: the assessee was not bound to furnish declarations in Form C before February 16, 1961

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the assessee was number bound to furnish declarations in Form C before February 16, 1961 in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct consequence of third proviso being ultra vires

holdings.text: the assessee has furnished the declarations in Form C in the present case within a reasonable time and there has been a compliance with the requirements of s. 8(4)(a) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the assessee has furnished the declarations in Form C in the present case within a ,reasonable time and there has been a companypliance with the requirements of s. 8  4   a  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Declarations filed March 8, 1961 before assessment order; delay explained by late receipt; constitutes reasonable time absent statutory limit

holdings.text: the phrase in the prescribed manner occurring in s. 8(4) of the Act only confers power on the rule-making authority to prescribe a rule stating what particulars are to be mentioned in the prescribed form, the nature and value of the goods sold, the parties to whom they are sold, and to which authority the form is to be furnished. But the phrase in the prescribed manner in s. 8(4) does not take in the time element

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the phrase in the prescribed manner occurring in s. 8 4  of the Act only companyfers power on the rule-making authority to prescribe a rule stating what particulars are to be mentioned in the prescribed form, the nature and value of the goods

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual construction limits to form content, parties, authority; excludes time as legislature specifies 'time within which' separately in s.13(4)(g)

holdings.text: the High Court was right in quashing the order of assessment made by the Sales Tax Officer and directing him to make a fresh order of assessment after taking into consideration the declaration forms furnished by the assessee on March 8, 1961

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the High Court was right in quashing the order of assessment made by the Sales Tax Officer and directing him to make a fresh order of assessment after taking into companysideration the declaration

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from compliance with s.8(4)(a) and invalidity of third proviso

precedents.cited_proposition: the words 'manner and form' refer only to the mode in which the thing is to be done, and do not introduce anything from the Act referred to as to the thing which is to be done or the time for doing it
precedents.cited_holding: The words in manner and form refer only to the mode in which the thing is to be done, and do number introduce anything from the Act referred to, as to the thing which is to be done or the time for doing it.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the assessee has furnished the declarations in Form C in the present case within a ,reasonable time and there has been a companypliance with the requirements of s. 8  4   a  of the Act. It follows that the High Court was right in quashing the order of assessment made by the Sales Tax Officer and directing him to make a fresh order of assessment after taking into companysideration the declaration forms furnished by the assessee on March 8, 1961.

outcome.relief_summary: Held that third proviso to Rule 6(1) ultra vires; assessee complied with s.8(4)(a) by filing declarations before assessment; High Court correctly quashed assessment orders and directed fresh assessment.
directions: Sales Tax Officer to make fresh order of assessment taking into consideration declaration forms furnished on March 8, 1961 (High Court order upheld).
